messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 49 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Stabilize to Act: Learning to Coordinate for Bimanual Manipulation

Paper Abstract: Abstract Key to rich, dexterous manipulation in the real world is the ability to coordinate control across two hands. However, while the promise afforded by bimanual robotic systems is immense, constructing control policies for dual arm autonomous systems brings inherent difficulties. One such difficulty is the high-dimensionality of the bimanual action space, which adds complexity to both model-based and data-driven methods. We counteract this challenge by drawing inspiration from humans to propose a novel role assignment framework: a stabilizing arm holds an object in place to simplify the environment while an acting arm executes the task. We instantiate this framework with BimanUal Dexterity from Stabilization (BUDS), which uses a learned restabilizing classifier to alternate between updating a learned stabilization position to keep the environment unchanged, and accomplishing the task with an acting policy learned from demonstrations. We evaluate BUDS on four bimanual tasks of varying complexities on real-world robots, such as zipping jackets and cutting vegetables. Given only 20 demonstrations, BUDS achieves 76.9% task success across our task suite, and generalizes to out-of-distribution objects within a class with a 52.7% success rate. BUDS is 56.0% more successful than a unstructured baseline that instead learns a BC stabilizing policy due to the precision required of these complex tasks. Supplementary material and videos can be found at https://tinyurl.com/stabilizetoact.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 49 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 49"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Learning from My Partner’s Actions: Roles in Decentralized Robot Teams",
        "It Takes Two: Learning to Plan for Human-Robot Cooperative Carrying",
        "Learning Bimanual Scooping Policies for Food Acquisition",
        "Sim2Real in Robotics and Automation: Applications and Challenges",
        "Deep Whole-Body Control: Learning a Unified Policy for Manipulation and Locomotion",
        "Towards Human-Level Bimanual Dexterous Manipulation with Reinforcement Learning",
        "Bi-Manual Manipulation and Attachment via Sim-to-Real Reinforcement Learning",
        "A system for imitation learning of contact-rich bimanual manipulation policies",
        "A review on reinforcement learning for contact-rich robotic manipulation tasks",
        "A Review of Robot Learning for Manipulation: Challenges, Representations, and Algorithms",
        "Constraints extraction from asymmetrical bimanual tasks and their use in coordinated behavior",
        "Dual arm manipulation—A survey",
        "Learning manipulation by sequencing motor primitives with a two-armed robot",
        "Learning fine-grained bimanual manipulation with low-cost hardware",
        "Deep imitation learning for bimanual robotic manipulation",
        "Learning Complex Manipulation Tasks from Heterogeneous and Unstructured Demonstrations",
        "Compliant movement primitives in a bimanual setting",
        "Dimensionality Reduction for Dynamic Movement Primitives and Application to Bimanual Manipulation of Clothes",
        "Reinforcement Learning of Bimanual Robot Skills",
        "Interactive imitation learning of bimanual movement primitives",
        "Efficient Bimanual Manipulation Using Learned Task Schemas",
        "Influencing towards stable multi-agent interactions",
        "Untangling Dense Knots by Learning Task-Relevant Keypoints",
        "SpeedFolding: Learning Efficient Bimanual Folding of Garments",
        "Learning Dense Visual Correspondences in Simulation to Smooth and Fold Real Fabrics",
        "Exploiting Symmetries in Reinforcement Learning of Bimanual Robotic Tasks",
        "Learning nonlinear dynamical system for movement primitives",
        "Safely Learning Visuo-Tactile Feedback Policies in Real For Industrial Insertion",
        "Intrinsic Motivation for Encouraging Synergistic Behavior",
        "Flingbot: The unreasonable effectiveness of dynamic manipulation for cloth unfolding",
        "Programming by Demonstration: Dual-Arm Manipulation Tasks for Humanoid Robots",
        "Coordinated control of multiple manipulator systems",
        "Dynamical System-Based Motion Planning for Multi-Arm Systems: Reaching for Moving Objects",
        "A certified-complete bimanual manipulation planner",
        "Dynamic model and simulation of cooperative robots: A case study",
        "Intelligent planning and control for multirobot coordination: An event-based approach",
        "Bimanual robotic cloth manipulation for laundry folding",
        "Fixture Planning With Friction",
        "Kinematic analysis of workpart fixturing for flexible assembly with automatically reconfigurable fixtures",
        "Learning to Scaffold the Development of Robotic Manipulation Skills",
        "Robust planning for multi-stage forceful manipulation",
        "Manipulation Planning under Changing External Forces",
        "Cooking behavior with handling general cooking tools based on a system integration for a life-sized humanoid robot",
        "Leveraging Multimodal Haptic Sensory Data for Robust Cutting",
        "Recognition and manipulation integration for a daily assistive robot working on kitchen environments",
        "Identity Mappings in Deep Residual Networks",
        "imgaug",
        "Adam: A method for stochastic optimization",
        "What matters in learning from offline human demonstrations for robot manipulation"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 49 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Stabilize to Act: Learning to Coordinate for Bimanual Manipulation, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
